Question Text: Which of the following are examples of control plane operations? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Rate-limiting traffic so that the overall sending rate does not exceed a certain throughput.
b. Determining that a user's MAC address is authentic before allowing it to send traffic on the network.
c. Load balancing traffic across two output ports based on the hash of each packet's source IP address.
d. Determining the forwarding path that satisfies an access control policy.
e. Computing a shortest path routing tree.
LLM Explanation:
Control plane functions make decisions about what should be done (routing, policy, authentication/authorization), while the data plane enforces those decisions per-packet (forwarding, policing, per-packet hashing for load distribution). 
- b: Authentication of a MAC address is an access-control/AAA decision — a control-plane operation. 
- d: Determining a forwarding path that satisfies an access-control policy is a control-plane policy/routing decision. 
- e: Computing a shortest-path routing tree (e.g., using Dijkstra) is a classic control-plane activity. 
Excluded: a (rate limiting/policing is a data‑plane enforcement function) and c (per‑packet hashing for load distribution is performed in the data plane; the control plane may install the group/ECMP rules but the per-packet hash/enforcement is data-plane).

Question Text: What could be the operational steps behind the AT&T's IRSCP (a commercial version of the Routing Control Platform) for detecting malicious traffic? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. The controller sees all traffic passing through the network, detects an attack, and installs a null route to drop traffic at the entry point where the attack traffic is originating.
b. The end host changes its IP address so that it is no longer the target of the attack traffic.
c. A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point of the attack, and instructs a controller to re-route traffic through a deep-packet inspection device.
d. A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point of the attack, and instructs a controller to install a null route to drop traffic at the entry point where attack traffic is originating.
e. A victim end host sends an alert to an on-path firewall about the source and nature of an attack, at which point the firewall installs a null route to drop the traffic at the entry point where the attack is originating.
LLM Explanation: AT&T’s commercial RCP/IRSCP-style deployments separate detection/measurement from routing actions. A measurement system (or monitoring probes) detects malicious traffic and identifies ingress points; the controller is then instructed to either steer traffic through a scrubbing/deep‑packet‑inspection device (c) or to install a null/black‑hole route at the ingress to drop the attack traffic (d). Option (a) is incorrect because the controller typically does not itself ‘‘see all traffic’’ end‑to‑end; it acts on signals from measurement systems. Option (b) (victim changing its address) is not a typical operational step of RCP/IRSCP. Option (e) is not representative: victim hosts don’t generally signal an on‑path firewall to push remote null routes at upstream entry points — that action is normally taken by the ISP/controller after measurement/analysis.

Question Text: What are some example network management applications that become easier with control and data plane separation? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Improved interdomain routing security.
b. Customer-controlled egress selection.
c. Improved logging capabilities.
d. Planned maintenance of an edge router.
e. Forecasting of network capacity.
LLM Explanation: With control/data-plane separation (SDN) a logically centralized controller has a global view and centralized policy/telemetry, which makes: (b) customer-controlled egress selection easier (controller can steer flows to chosen egress points), (c) improved logging/monitoring easier (centralized collection and correlation of flow/state data), (d) planned maintenance of an edge router easier (controller can proactively reroute flows and update forwarding state), and (e) capacity forecasting easier (global utilization data enables better traffic and capacity forecasting). (a) Improved interdomain routing security is not a direct consequence: interdomain (BGP) security requires cross‑domain mechanisms and deployment (RPKI/BGPsec, policy exchange) and cannot be solved solely by separating control and data planes inside one administrative domain.
URLs: ['https://arxiv.org/abs/1406.0440 (Kreutz et al., "Software-Defined Networking: A Comprehensive Survey")', 'https://opennetworking.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/technical-report-SDN-and-OpenFlow.pdf (Open Networking Foundation SDN overview)', 'https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7454 (IETF: Recommendations for Inter‑Domain Routing Security)', 'https://www.sigcomm.org/sites/default/files/ccr/papers/2008/July/116-127.pdf (McKeown et al., OpenFlow/SDN concepts)']

Question Text: What are some of the motivations for using Layer-2 forwarding in a data center? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Ability to use existing routing protocols to establish paths between hosts.
b. Easier configuration/administration, since there is no need to number hosts or configure subnets.
c. Better security properties.
d. Better scaling properties.
e. Better load balancing properties.
LLM Explanation:
b: True — Layer‑2 forwarding keeps hosts in the same broadcast/subnet, so moving VMs or hosts across the fabric does not require renumbering or reconfiguring IP subnets (simplifies configuration and administration).
e: True — While classic flat L2 has limits, modern L2 fabric technologies (e.g., TRILL, SPB, VXLAN+EVPN) provide multipath forwarding at L2 and enable better utilization of multiple links for load balancing across the data‑center fabric. 
Incorrect options: a is incorrect because using routing protocols to establish paths is an L3 behavior (routing), not a reason to choose L2. c is incorrect because L2 generally exposes larger broadcast domains and is more susceptible to ARP/spoofing issues unless additional controls are applied. d is incorrect because pure L2 flat designs typically scale worse (broadcast domains, large MAC tables) than properly designed L3 hierarchical fabrics.

Question Text: How does the separation of the control and data plane make networking in data centers easier?
Choices:
a. Virtual machines can be migrated within the network without renumbering entire portions of the network or re-assigning network services to different IP addresses.
b. The control plane allows traffic to be forwarded using Layer 2 addresses, thus allowing automatic load balance across the topology.
c. The separation allows fewer switches to be used in the data center topology, thus lowering costs.
d. All routes can be controlled and monitored from a central point of control.
e. A network controller can permit the renumbering of end hosts to have topology-dependent Layer 2 MAC addresses.
LLM Explanation: a: True — separating control and data planes (SDN) centralizes forwarding logic in a controller, which can reprogram forwarding state (or instantiate overlays like VXLAN) to enable VM mobility without renumbering or reassigning services. d: True — SDN centralizes routing/policy decisions so routes can be controlled and monitored from a central controller. b: False — forwarding using L2 addresses is a data‑plane function; SDN enables programmable forwarding and custom load‑balancing policies but does not inherently make L2 forwarding produce automatic topology‑wide load balancing as stated. c: False — SDN does not inherently reduce the physical number of switches required in a data center. e: False — renumbering end hosts to topology‑dependent MACs is neither required nor a typical benefit of controller separation; controllers normally decouple host identity from topology (not force topology‑dependent MAC renumbering).

Question Text: What are some examples of problems that can arise from consistency problems in the control plane, where a network has multiple controller replicas?
Choices:
a. A flood of traffic at the controller.
b. Inability to respond to link failures.
c. Incorrect security policies.
d. Incorrect operation when one controller fails.
e. Forwarding loops.
LLM Explanation: Consistency problems across multiple controller replicas cause divergent or stale views of topology and policy. This can (b) prevent correct/faster reaction to link failures if some replicas do not see the failure or do not install the same reroutes; (c) cause inconsistent or incorrect enforcement of security policies if replicas disagree on ACLs/flow rules; (d) produce incorrect behavior after a controller failover when the backup has stale/inconsistent state; and (e) create transient or persistent forwarding loops when different switches receive inconsistent forwarding rules during updates. Option (a) — a flood of traffic at the controller — is not a typical direct consequence of replica consistency problems (it is more commonly caused by reactive mode, missing flow rules, or DoS), so it is excluded.
URLs: ['https://www.cs.princeton.edu/~rjg/papers/sigcomm12.pdf (Reitblatt et al., "Abstractions for Network Update" / consistent updates — loops and blackholes)', 'https://arxiv.org/abs/1406.0440 (Kreutz et al., "Software-Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Survey" — discusses distributed control, consistency and its effects)', 'https://conferences.sigcomm.org/sigcomm/2008/papers/p243-koponen.pdf (Koponen et al., "Onix: A Distributed Control Platform" — design tradeoffs and consistency issues)', 'https://wiki.onosproject.org/display/ONOS/Architecture (ONOS docs — distributed controller consistency and failover implications)']

Question Text: What are some approaches to coping with inconsistency across controller replicas? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Running a consistency protocol across controller replicas.
b. Keeping a "hot spare" replica that has a complete view of the network state.
c. Only keeping a subset of the network state in memory at any time.
d. Using different controllers for independent parts of the network.
e. Having multiple controllers install forwarding table entries on the same router and resolving the conflict on the router itself.
LLM Explanation: a) Running a consistency protocol (e.g., Paxos/Raft or state-machine replication) is a standard way to keep controller replicas consistent. b) A primary/backup (hot-spare) design where a backup maintains a complete, up-to-date view and takes over on failure is a common practical approach to tolerate replica inconsistency/failures. d) Partitioning the network so different controllers manage independent parts reduces the need for cross-replica synchronization (sharding the control state). Option c is about memory usage, not inconsistency mitigation. Option e (letting multiple controllers write the same switch and resolve conflicts on the switch) is not a typical/reliable approach to handle controller-state inconsistency and is generally undesirable because it shifts complex conflict resolution to data-plane devices and can produce incorrect behavior.
URLs: ['https://arxiv.org/abs/1406.0440 (Kreutz et al., "Software-Defined Networking: A Comprehensive Survey")', 'https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/publication/onix-large-scale-network-control-platform/ (Onix platform paper)', 'https://raft.github.io/raft.pdf (Diego Ongaro & John Ousterhout, Raft consensus algorithm)', 'https://onosproject.org/ (ONOS — distributed controller architecture and availability design)', 'https://opennetworking.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/openflow-spec-v1.3.0.pdf (OpenFlow switch specification — controller roles and flow rule semantics)']

Question Text: What are some approaches to coping with scalability challenges associated with control and data plane separation? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Caching forwarding decisions in the data plane to reduce traffic at the controller.
b. Only performing control-plane operations for a limited set of network operations.
c. Eliminating redundant data structures.
d. Sending all traffic through the controller to minimize forwarding decisions that the routers and switches must make.
e. Running multiple controllers, and having each controller only manage a part of the network.
LLM Explanation: a) Caching forwarding decisions in the data plane (e.g., flow table entries, wildcard/proactive rules, local fast-paths) reduces the number of control-plane interactions and controller load. b) Limiting the set of operations the controller must handle (offloading routine/local decisions to the data plane or handling only exceptions) reduces control-plane traffic and processing. c) Eliminating redundant state/data structures (reducing duplicated state, compacting representations, avoiding unnecessary replication) lowers memory, synchronization, and update costs and helps scale. d) is incorrect — routing all traffic through the controller is the opposite of a scalability solution (it creates a bottleneck). e) Running multiple controllers (distributed or hierarchical control-plane designs) partitions management and spreads load, improving scalability and fault tolerance.
URLs: ['https://opennetworking.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/sdn-definition.pdf (Open Networking Foundation SDN definition)', 'Kreutz, D., Ramos, F.M.V., Verissimo, P.E., et al., "Software-Defined Networking: A Comprehensive Survey," Proc. IEEE, 2015. https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/7123563', 'OpenFlow Switch Specification v1.3.3. https://opennetworking.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/openflow-spec-v1.3.3.pdf', 'Casado, M., et al., "DevoFlow: Scaling Flow Management for High-performance Networks," NSDI 2012. https://www.usenix.org/system/files/conference/nsdi12/nsdi12-final45.pdf', 'ONOS Project — Architecture (distributed controller approaches). https://wiki.onosproject.org/display/ONOS/ONOS+Architecture']

Question Text: Which property guarantees that each RCP replica continues to install correct forwarding state in the network data plane, even in the case of a partition in the data plane?
Choices:
a. Each controller has a complete view of the portion of the network that it is controlling, and therefore can guarantee consistent routing within that partition.
b. The controller cannot see many of the routers in the network anyway, so there is no way for it to install incorrect routing state in the routers that it is not connected to.
c. The controllers are partitioned from the network routers, and the routers will fall back to running a distributed routing protocol.
d. Running the network from a single high-level control plane guarantees that network partitions and loops never occur in the first place.
LLM Explanation: Option (a) is correct. RCP replicas are designed so each controller maintains a complete, authoritative view of the part of the network it controls; therefore when the data plane is partitioned a replica that still has reachability to the routers in its partition can continue to compute and install correct, consistent forwarding state for that partition. The other choices are incorrect: (b) is a mistaken justification, (c) describes a fallback to distributed routing (not the RCP guarantee), and (d) is false—a single control plane does not magically prevent partitions or loops.
URLs: ['https://www.cs.princeton.edu/~jrex/papers/rcp-sigcomm04.pdf', 'https://arxiv.org/abs/1406.0440 (Kreutz et al., "Software-Defined Networking: A Comprehensive Survey")', 'https://opennetworking.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/sdn-resources.pdf (Open Networking Foundation, SDN materials)']
